articles.headline: After Test Results, European Banks Are Urged to Bolster Reserves
articles.snippet: Eight banks failed and an additional 16 barely passed the much-anticipated stress tests, which measured whether they would be able to survive economic shocks.
articles.abstract: Eight banks failed and an additional 16 barely passed the much-anticipated stress tests, which measured whether they would be able to survive economic shocks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — About two dozen European banks were put under official pressure Friday to bolster their reserves, as the results of financial stress tests created more skepticism over the region’s will to deal with its festering financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Julia Werdigier and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Consumer Watchdog Is All Ears for Ideas
articles.snippet: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been soliciting ideas from the public, and the public has responded with an explosion of ideas, four of which seem to have real potential.
articles.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has been soliciting ideas from the public, and the public has responded with an explosion of ideas, four of which seem to have real potential.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you want to try your hand at playing regulator, now’s your chance.

articles.headline: As a Watchdog Starves, Wall Street Is Tossed a Bone
articles.snippet: The House Appropriations Committee is starving the S.E.C. while putting over $200 million back into the pockets of Wall Street.
articles.abstract: The House Appropriations Committee is starving the S.E.C. while putting over $200 million back into the pockets of Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: The economy is still suffering from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, and widespread anger persists that financial institutions that caused it received bailouts of billions of taxpayer dollars and haven’t been held accountable for any wrongdoing. Yet the House Appropriations Committee has responded by starving the agency responsible for bringing financial wrongdoers to justice — while putting over $200 million that could otherwise have been spent on investigations and enforcement actions back into the pockets of Wall Street.

articles.headline: Food Companies Act to Protect Consumers From E. Coli Illness
articles.snippet: Tired of waiting for federal regulators to act, Costco and Beef Products Inc. are requiring broader testing for more strains of the bacteria in their food.
articles.abstract: Tired of waiting for federal regulators to act, Costco and Beef Products Inc. are requiring broader testing for more strains of the bacteria in their food.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government has spent years considering whether to take steps to help keep dangerous strains of E. coli bacteria out of the food supply, a question that has become even more urgent in the face of a deadly wave of E. coli sickness that swept through Europe and raised alarms on both sides of the Atlantic.

articles.headline: After Long Battle, Safer Cribs
articles.snippet: New regulations for cribs took effect on June 28, but some makers had not had all of their cribs certified by testing laboratories, frustrating retailers.
articles.abstract: New regulations for cribs took effect on June 28, but some makers had not had all of their cribs certified by testing laboratories, frustrating retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYONNE, N.J. — At the back of a cavernous warehouse along a rough-and-tumble waterfront here, an area has been swept clean of boxes and forklifts to make way for baby safety.

articles.headline: Fallback Plan Moving to Fore as Budget Talks Stall
articles.snippet: Congressional leaders are negotiating a fallback plan as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion.
articles.abstract: Congressional leaders are negotiating a fallback plan as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With talks on a big budget deal at a stalemate, Congressional leaders turned Friday to negotiating a fallback plan for raising the debt limit as President Obama and House Republicans intensified their efforts to win over public opinion for the long battle ahead.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Misery Follows as Somalis Try to Flee Hunger
articles.snippet: Many Somalis, fleeing one of the worst droughts in the country in 60 years, have walked for weeks through an anarchic landscape replete with bandits and militants but little food.
articles.abstract: Many Somalis, fleeing one of the worst droughts in the country in 60 years, have walked for weeks through an anarchic landscape replete with bandits and militants but little food.
articles.lead_paragraph: DADAAB, Kenya — The people start trudging in at dawn, more than a thousand every day, exhausted, sick and starving, materializing out of the thin desert air to take their places at the gates of the world’s largest refugee camp, here in northern Kenya.

articles.headline: A Voice for Those Silenced in a Mobster’s Reign
articles.snippet: The Whitey Bulger case has drawn the ire of many, especially Tommy Donahue, whose father is one of 19 people Mr. Bulger is accused of killing.
articles.abstract: The Whitey Bulger case has drawn the ire of many, especially Tommy Donahue, whose father is one of 19 people Mr. Bulger is accused of killing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Heads turned as the lanky man made his way to the courtroom pews reserved for those who suffer because of the criminal Whitey Bulger. The face of an altar boy masked his rage, and a shirt of powder-blue covered his tattoos, including one evoking the Celtic cross that adorns his father’s gravestone.

articles.headline: 2nd Loans, 2nd Wave of Losses
articles.snippet: Banks have so far written down only a small portion of their second-lien mortgage loans. As home values in some areas continue to sink, more losses may be in store.
articles.abstract: Banks have so far written down only a small portion of their second-lien mortgage loans. As home values in some areas continue to sink, more losses may be in store.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVE you heard the good news? Big banks are making more money than we thought.

articles.headline: Law School Economics: Ka-Ching!
articles.snippet: Despite fewer high-paying jobs, students continue to pour into law school. And the schools keep charging higher tuition and admitting more students.
articles.abstract: Despite fewer high-paying jobs, students continue to pour into law school. And the schools keep charging higher tuition and admitting more students.
articles.lead_paragraph: WITH apologies to show business, there’s no business like the business of law school.

articles.headline: Stain From Tabloids Rubs Off on a Cozy Scotland Yard
articles.snippet: Testimony and new evidence indicate that Scotland Yard and News International became so intertwined that they wound up sharing the goal of containing the phone-hacking investigation.
articles.abstract: Testimony and new evidence indicate that Scotland Yard and News International became so intertwined that they wound up sharing the goal of containing the phone-hacking investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — For nearly four years they lay piled in a Scotland Yard evidence room, six overstuffed plastic bags gathering dust and little else.

articles.headline: Arab Spring, Start-Up Summer?
articles.snippet: Egypt’s revolution has sent the economy into a tailspin, but an emerging class of young entrepreneurs hopes to make the country a technology hot spot.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s revolution has sent the economy into a tailspin, but an emerging class of young entrepreneurs hopes to make the country a technology hot spot.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE so many other young people in Cairo, Yasmine el-Mehairy saw no future in Egypt. What she saw was a dead end.

articles.headline: An Alarming New Stimulant, Legal in Many States
articles.snippet: Doctors say the new drug that people call “bath salts” has unusually dangerous and long-lasting effects.
articles.abstract: Doctors say the new drug that people call “bath salts” has unusually dangerous and long-lasting effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Jeffrey J. Narmi could not believe what he was seeing this spring in the emergency room at Schuylkill Medical Center in Pottsville, Pa.: people arriving so agitated, violent and psychotic that a small army of medical workers was needed to hold them down.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Katie Zezima

articles.headline: For Bachmann, Gay Rights Stand Reflects Mix of Issues and Faith
articles.snippet: Michele Bachmann’s political rise has its roots in her dogged fight against same-sex marriage and her mixing of politics with her evangelical faith.
articles.abstract: Michele Bachmann’s political rise has its roots in her dogged fight against same-sex marriage and her mixing of politics with her evangelical faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PAUL — In March 2004, with Massachusetts soon to allow gay couples to wed, Michele Bachmann delivered a dire warning to her fellow Minnesotans: The children of their state were at risk.

articles.headline: Egypt Military Aims to Cement Muscular Role in Government
articles.snippet: The military council governing Egypt is moving to lay down ground rules for a new constitution that would potentially expand its authority indefinitely.
articles.abstract: The military council governing Egypt is moving to lay down ground rules for a new constitution that would potentially expand its authority indefinitely.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The military council governing Egypt is moving to lay down ground rules for a new constitution that would protect and potentially expand its own authority indefinitely, possibly circumscribing the power of future elected officials.

articles.headline: An Arrest and Scotland Yard Resignation Roil Britain
articles.snippet: Britain’s most highly ranked police official resigned, and Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International, was arrested.
articles.abstract: Britain’s most highly ranked police official resigned, and Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of News International, was arrested.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain’s top police official resigned on Sunday, the latest casualty of the phone-hacking scandal engulfing British public life, just hours after Rebekah Brooks, the former chief executive of Rupert Murdoch’s News International, was arrested on suspicion of illegally intercepting phone calls and bribing the police.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: Former Ohio Attorney General to Head New Consumer Agency
articles.snippet: In picking Richard Cordray, President Obama passed over Elizabeth Warren, who drew strong opposition from Republicans.
articles.abstract: In picking Richard Cordray, President Obama passed over Elizabeth Warren, who drew strong opposition from Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said Sunday that he would nominate Richard Cordray, the former attorney general of Ohio, to lead the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, passing over Elizabeth Warren, the Harvard law professor who was the driving force behind the agency’s creation.

articles.headline: To Pique Interest, Start-Ups Try a Digital Velvet Rope
articles.snippet: These days it can be hard for a new Web site to attract attention. So many companies have tried creating a sense of exclusivity.
articles.abstract: These days it can be hard for a new Web site to attract attention. So many companies have tried creating a sense of exclusivity.
articles.lead_paragraph: Demand for Google’s new social networking service, Google+, has been intense since its debut last month in a limited test mode. To get in, you must be invited by someone who is already a member, so Facebook and Twitter are peppered with requests for invitations to the service, and they have even been sold on eBay.

articles.headline: Pain Builds in Europe’s Sovereign Debt Risk
articles.snippet: The latest bank stress test revealed how exposed banks are to the government bonds of Greece, Portugal, Spain and Italy.
articles.abstract: The latest bank stress test revealed how exposed banks are to the government bonds of Greece, Portugal, Spain and Italy.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European banks for years bolstered their balance sheets with assets considered safe and secure: the sovereign debt of European countries.

articles.headline: Sony, Like Old Hollywood, Banks on Familiar Faces
articles.snippet: Sony has emerged as perhaps the closest contemporary approximation of a classic studio: its movies change, but those who make them remain remarkably consistent.
articles.abstract: Sony has emerged as perhaps the closest contemporary approximation of a classic studio: its movies change, but those who make them remain remarkably consistent.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — If Louis B. Mayer haunts the Irving Thalberg Building, once his seat of power at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, he may recognize more than the walnut walls. The building is now the home of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and there are signs that Mayer’s old studio system is being revived.

articles.headline: App Makers and Twitter Feel Strains
articles.snippet: A boom in apps has fed longstanding tensions between Twitter and the developers over whether they are partners or competitors.
articles.abstract: A boom in apps has fed longstanding tensions between Twitter and the developers over whether they are partners or competitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The relationship between Twitter and the outside developers that build its apps is a little like the one between sharks and the small fish that latch onto their backs — beneficial for both, until it isn’t.

articles.headline: Troubles That Money Can’t Dispel
articles.snippet: The willingness of the News Corporation to spend millions in settlement costs to make problems go away provides a useful window into its larger culture.
articles.abstract: The willingness of the News Corporation to spend millions in settlement costs to make problems go away provides a useful window into its larger culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Bury your mistakes,” Rupert Murdoch is fond of saying. But some mistakes don’t stay buried, no matter how much money you throw at them.

articles.headline: Fast Traders, in Spotlight, Battle Rules
articles.snippet: High-frequency trading firms, for years accused of hurting ordinary investors, are turning away from their normal secrecy in an attempt to buff their tarnished image.
articles.abstract: High-frequency trading firms, for years accused of hurting ordinary investors, are turning away from their normal secrecy in an attempt to buff their tarnished image.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years they have operated in the shadows, often far from Wall Street, trading stocks at warp speed and reaping billions while criticism rose that they were damaging markets and hurting ordinary investors.

articles.headline: At Stores, Making 5 for $5 a Bigger Draw Than 1 for $1
articles.snippet: With grocery shoppers more price conscious, stores are offering larger quantities of items to entice them to buy more.
articles.abstract: With grocery shoppers more price conscious, stores are offering larger quantities of items to entice them to buy more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Buy a lot — a whole lot more than you meant to — and save!

articles.headline: In Sierra Leone, New Hope for Children and Pregnant Women
articles.snippet: Health care is making enormous strides in Sierra Leone, the latest country in sub-Saharan Africa to waive hospital fees, particularly for children and pregnant women.
articles.abstract: Health care is making enormous strides in Sierra Leone, the latest country in sub-Saharan Africa to waive hospital fees, particularly for children and pregnant women.
articles.lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Sierra Leone — The paramedic’s eyes were bloodshot, his features drawn. Pregnant women jammed into the darkened concrete bunker, just as they had yesterday and would tomorrow. The increase in patients had been fivefold, or tenfold. The exhausted paramedic had lost count in a blur of uninterrupted examinations and deliveries.

articles.headline: Coming Together to Fight for a Troubled Veteran
articles.snippet: Headed for disaster after returning from Iraq, Staff Sgt. Brad Eifert was spared with the help of a novel court program and an unlikely group of people.
articles.abstract: Headed for disaster after returning from Iraq, Staff Sgt. Brad Eifert was spared with the help of a novel court program and an unlikely group of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: OKEMOS, Mich. — When the standoff began on a humid August night, it seemed destined to become one more case of a returned soldier pulled down by a war he could not leave behind.

articles.headline: Opponents Seize on Cameron’s Ties to Suspects
articles.snippet: A reinvigorated Labour Party is posing a fresh challenge to the young government of Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain.
articles.abstract: A reinvigorated Labour Party is posing a fresh challenge to the young government of Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron cut short a state visit to Africa as he confronted a growing scandal over his cozy ties with Rupert Murdoch’s top lieutenants in Britain and the challenge it posed to his year-old government.
